item.description: Tetris for two. A fun tetris game with many different game modes

item.title: Programmer-for-hire
item.description: I may be available for software engineering contracting work. With my full stack skillset, I can create (or update) a website, webapp, or Android app from start to finish. Programming Languages I know the following languages: Python including Tensorflow and other machine learning and data science tools. JavaScript including ES6, NodeJS, and other web development tools C C++, including Qt and the language QML Java Haskell Elm Lisp Rust I have experience with the Linux operating system.

item.title: Tutoring
item.description: I am your math, language, and programming tutor Qualifications: I worked as a tutor at the Computer Science department of the New Mexico Institute of Mining and Technology for two years. I have a degree in mathematics and a degree in computer science from the same school, where I graduated with a 3.5 GPA in 4.5 years. I tutored middle-school as part of the Growing Up Thinking Scientifically (GUTS) program and high-school students in the Supercomputing Challenge.

item.title: does-it-live
item.description: Website uptime checker

item.title: cheatsheets
item.description: Toolkit for converting notes into compact PDFs suitable for quick reference sheets, cheatsheets, cribsheets, etc. Notes can be written in markdown, are rendered to PDF by Pandoc.

item.title: passwordstore-noise-generator
item.description: Patches up a possible side-channel in zx2c4’s pass password manager.

item.description: Boilerplate and tooling for authoring data API backends with Node.js and GraphQL. A personal fork.

item.title: Linux and MacOS configuration files
item.description: My portable, personal, developer-centric setup for common Linux and MacOS tools.

item.description: A personal fork of ▁▅▆▃▅ git-quick-statistics, a simple and efficient way to access various statistics in git repository

item.title: pympw
item.description: A Python implementation of the Master Password algorithm v3 with a nice Linux CLI

item.title: polybar-themer
item.description: A theme generator for polybar, a popular status bar for Linux. Uses math and advanced YAML parsing to generate colorful, sensible color schemes.

item.title: ocaml-parsing
item.description: Boilerplate code for writing parsers in OCaml using Menhir + sedlex

item.title: cuda-fft
item.description: Yet another FFT implementation in CUDA. Includes benchmarks using simple data for comparing different implementations.

item.description: Write a résumé in markdown and convert to PDF, DOCX, and HTML.

item.title: ansible-fwknop
item.description: Ansible role that secures ports on your server from unauthorized access using fwknop, an improved port knocking utility.

item.title: PhotoFest
item.description: PhotoFest is a secure self-hosted flat-file photo collection webapp written in Rust (unfinished)

item.title: email-classifier
item.description: A machine learning project for classifying emails into spam and ham. Uses C for preprocessing emails, Python for parsing and extracting low-level features of emails, and a few lines of Matlab for running several classic classifiers.

item.title: qtdemo
item.description: A test of the features of the C++ framework Qt5, especially for Android apps.

item.title: coolnoise
item.description: Parser and generator for programs written in the Classroom Object-Oriented Language. Eases testing of lexer and parser.

item.title: New Mexico Tech's Introduction to Python and Programming Labs (CS 107)
item.description: Carefully written and formatted. I wrote much of the copy-editing and some of the LaTeX for this year’s version of the labs.

item.title: cv-composer
item.description: Command-line based computer vision algorithms showcase. Uses the OpenCV C++ library.

item.title: hopfield_tests
item.description: These Python scripts can be used to test the recall effectiveness of Hopfield Networks. A sample dataset composed of the Walsh vectors, an orthogonal system is included by default.

item.title: Notes on Chemistry the Central Science
item.description: See github.com/roguh/chemistry_the_central_science.

item.title: Notes on Perception for Design
item.description: I took concise notes based on the excellent, scientifically-rigorous textbook Information Visualization: Perception for Design by Colin Ware. I created this PDF using LaTeX, which allowed me the flexibility to create an easy-to-edit, elegant, and compact document layout. I highly recommend the book and these notes for anyone that needs to create data visualizations. See here.

item.title: CORE
item.description: Implementation of SPJ’s Tutorial Core compilers in modern Haskell (unfinished)

item.title: SCMinHS
item.description: A Scheme Implementation in Haskell. Followed “Write Yourself a Scheme in 48 Hours.”
